metadata.title: Stable silica-grafted polymer-bound bulky-phosphite modified rhodium hydroformylation catalysts

V.), Badhuisweg 3, 1031 CM Amsterdam (Netherlands) (Received July 20,1992; accepted March 17, 1993 ) Abstract The present study demonstrates that silica-grafted polymer-bound phosphite modified rhodium complexes can be used in continuous flow reactors. The hydroformylation of styrene was carried out at moderate pressure (p (CO/HZ) - 30 bar) and temperature (T-100 C), yielding constant conversions over a period of at least ten days. Leakage of rhodium is prevented totally and no decay in catalyst activity was observed. These positive results were obtained in benzene as a solvent and for a ligand to rhodium ratio of only 4. When toluene was used as solvent, considerable rhodium leaching was observed. This could be attributed to contraction of the grafted polymer coils in this solvent, leading to incomplete coordination of rhodium. Key words: hydroformylation; phosphites; polymer-bound catalysts; rhodium Introduction Homogeneous catalysts are superior in activity, selectivity as well as specificity, but heterogeneous catalysts are often preferred in industrial processes, because of their good recoverability and their applicability in continuous flow reactors. It would be of great environmental, commercial and scientific interest to combine the advantages of both catalysts [ 1 ] . A route to achieve this goal is to immobilize a potent homogeneous catalyst onto an insoluble resin. Synthetic polymers are inert materials which can easily be modified and therefore have found widespread use as support materials for catalysts [ 2 ] . Most authors used crosslinked polystyrene resins as the catalyst support, either with a low crosslink density (gel type resins) or high crosslink density (macroporous beads). Diffusion limitation of substrate and/or product, resulting in a lower "Corresponding author. 0304-5102/93/$06.00 1993 - Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. 38 T. Jongsma et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 83 (1993) 37-50 activity for the polymer-bound catalyst in comparison with its low molecular weight analogue, is the major disadvantage of gel type resins. Macroporous resins do not have this disadvantage, but low physical strength [ 3 ] and inaccessibility of the bulk of the polymer are the drawbacks of this material. To avoid these problems an alternative approach was followed in this study. A stable homogeneous catalyst was attached to a soluble linear polymer chain (Fig. la, b). This system is homogeneous, and thus diffusion limitation is much less likely to occur. In the next step, the polymer chain is grafted on the surface of an inert support (Fig. lc). The polymer chains form expanded coils, so the active species is still homogeneous, but the system is immobilized and can easily be recovered. This method has already been applied successfully to immidazole modified copper catalysts [4 ] . The low molecular weight model catalyst used in this study is a bulky phosphite modified rhodium complex. Bulky phosphite modified rhodium complexes are good hydroformylation catalysts [5 ] . The good stability of (aryl) phosphites and the strong metal-ligand bond induced by the relatively high nacidity [6] of the ligand makes them very suitable for use in polymer-bound (a) Cat. (c) Cat. Cat. Cat. SiU2 cat. Cat. / cat. Cal. Cal. Cat. Cat. ' Cat. Cat (cal.; (cal.; Fig. 1. (a) Highly active homogeneous catalyst, (b) polymer-bound catalysts, (c) polymer-bound catalysts grafted onto an inert insoluble silica sphere. The catalytic species are still homogeneous, but the system is heterogenized. T. Jongsma et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 83 (1993) 37-50 39 H -CH=-CH-CH2-CH- -CH=-C-CHi-CH- * * -P I V@ P P O Scheme 1. Phenol exchange of polymer-bound triphenyl phosphite to give free triphenyl phosphite. (The phosphite ligands are not necessarily neighbouring groups on the polymer chain.) catalyst systems. Therefore ligand degradation or metal-ligand bond fracture leading to metal leaching in continuous flow reactors may be prevented. The silica-grafted polymer-bound 2,2' -bis (4,6-di-t-butylphenyl) phenyl phosphite (1) is used as the ligand for rhodium in this study. R- -CHi-CH- Sio= A o (1) P j t n R = initiator residue The advantage of this phosphite is that phenol exchange (Scheme 1), which might lead to detachment of the ligand from the polymer chain and eventually elution of rhodium, is prevented by the chelating bis-phenogy group. The low molecular weight analogue 2,2' -bis (4,6-di-t-butylphenyl) phenyl phosphite as well as the non-grafted polymer, form active hydroformylation complexes with rhodium [7]. For the non-grafted (co)polymer-bound catalysts a copolymer of 2,2' -bis (4,6-di-t-butylphenyl) atyryl phosphite and styrene yielded more active catalysts. The most active hydroformylation catalysts were formed with copolymers with a low chain loading (a) with ligand groups. However, the use of these polymers in the silica-grafted system eventually led to deactivation of the catalyst, probably due to the formation of dimeric or clustered rhodium complexes. Therefore, the homopolymer (a= 1), which forms stable bisphosphite coordinated rhodium complexes in the non-grafted system, was applied in the present study. Prior to the reaction of the covalently silica bound 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane group with 4,4' -azo-bis (4-cyanopentanoic acid chloride) the residual hydroxyl groups of the silica surface were reacted with 1,1,1,3,3,3-hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS );16 ml of HMDS was added to a dispersion of 8 g modified silica in 80 ml toluene and stirred at room temperature for 4 h. The modified silica spheres were washed with toluene and diethyl ether and centrifuged. Afterwards the modified silica was dried in vacuo for 16 h. Further modification of the silica was carried in accord with the prescribed procedure. The number of initiator residues per gram silica was determined with elemental (nitrogen) analysis (0.2 mmol initiator/g silica). 4-t-Butoxycarbonyloxystyrene 4-t-Butoxycarbonyloxystyrene was synthesized as described by Frechet et al. Graft polymerization of 4-t-butoxycarbonyloxystyrene from silica (Scheme 2) A 2.2 gram amount of azo-initiator modified silica was suspended in 13.3 ml 4-t-butoxycarbonyloxystyrene and 3.5 ml toluene. The suspension was stirred at 70 C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature and adding 100 ml of toluene, the suspension is centrifuged. The product was washed with toluene twice. The silica-grafted polymers were not dried, but kept in toluene suspension. The supernatant toluene layers were concentrated and added dropwise to a 10-fold excess of methanol. Silica-grafted poly(4-hydroxystyrene) The solvent of the silica-grafted polymer suspension described in the previous section was exchanged by 60 ml sulfolane. The sulfolane suspension was heated for 15 min at 200 C under N2 atmosphere. The evolving C02 gas was trapped in a NaOH/P205 tube and determined gravimetrically. From the amount of C02 formed, the amount of phenol groups could be estimated. After cooling the solution to 50 C,100 ml THF was added, the spheres were centrifuged and washed twice with THF. 2,2'-Bis (4,6-di-t-butylphenyl) chloro phosphite The 2,2'-bas (4,6-di-t-butylphenyl)chloro phosphite was synthesized as described previously [ 7 ] . Silica-grafted poly(2,2'-bas (4,6-di-t-butylphenyl) styryl phosphate) To a well stirred, heated suspension (T- 60 C) of the silica-grafted poly (4hydroxystyrene) and 7 g of 2,2' -bas (4,6-di-t-butylphenyl) chloro phosphite in 150 ml THF, a solution of 3 g of lithium 2,6-di-t-butylphenolate in 50 ml THF was added dropwise in 3 hours. The suspension was stirred overnight, cooled and centrifuged. The silica-grafted polymer was washed with THF twice and subsequently twice with toluene. The product was stored as a suspension in toluene. Results; 1.02 g grafted polymer/g silica, 31P NMR in CDC13,140 ppm (s), line width 400 Hz. Rhodium(2,4 OntOionato)cyclooctadiene (Rh(acac)COD) The rhodium precursor Rh (acac) COD was prepared as described previously [ 10 ] . 42 T. Jongsma et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 83 (1993) 37-50 Kinetic measurements Batch experiments Batch experiments were carried out in a stainless steel (AISI 316) autoclave of 100 ml at constant CO and H2 pressure and at constant temperature. For a standard experiment the reaction vessel was charged with 20 ml of toluene, 0.1 ml of decane (internal standard for GLC analysis) and the desired amount of silica-grafted polymer-bound phosphite and Rh(acac)COD. The reaction mixture was heated to the desired temperature, 0.2 ml of substrate (styrene) was added and the autoclave pressurized. During the reaction samples were drawn and the aldehyde content was determined with a Packard 419 GLC apparatus equipped with a SE-30 column. The peaks of the two reaction products for styrene (branched and linear aldehydes) were summed. The product distribution of these two products under the given conditions was found to be 35% linear and 65% branched. The conversion is plotted against time. From the slope of the plot of In (1-conversion) versus time a reaction constant k (s-1) can be calculated. This reaction rate constant was normalized for the amount of rhodium used by dividing k by the rhodium concentration, yielding kobe (1/s mol ). Some samples were also analyzed in a Mattson FTIR spectrometer (NaCl cell, 0.1 mm). The metal-carbonyl absorption region from 20002200 cm-1 was not disturbed by solvent peaks. The results are summarized in Table 1. Continuous flow experiments Continuous flow experiments were carried out in a stainless steel (AISI 316) autoclave system, a continuously stirred tank reactor (CSTR) as depicted in Fig. 2. In this setup only one simple plunger pump is needed, and the liquid can be maintained at the same level without a measuring device. The product is pumped (1, Spectra Physics 3500 B, or a Morgan 55-DS plunger pump with a TR-2 timing relay) from the reaction vessel (4) to the glass bucket (6) which floats on the substrate solution in the stock autoclave (5) . The reactor (4) is charged with the silica-grafted polymer-bound phosphite which is mixed with the catalyst precursor Rh (acac) COD and suspended in the sol- TABLE 1 Batch hydroformylation reactions under different conditionsa Egp. For a typical reaction, the reaction vessel (4) is charged with 2.5 mg of Rh (acac) COD and 35 mg silica-grafted polymer-bound phosphites (1) in 7 ml toluene or benzene. The stock autoclave (5) is filled with 40 ml styrene, 20 ml decane and 360 ml toluene or benzene. The reaction conditions and results are summarized in Table 2. Results Batch experiments The batch experiments carried out in toluene show very unique kinetics (Fig. 3 ). During the first period the reaction is first order in substrate, as expected from earlier experiments with non-grafted polymer-bound catalysts and the low molecular weight analogue of the catalyst [ 7 ] . The activity of the catalyst is first order in the substrate concentration during the entire reaction period. Flow 2.4 ml/h, reaction volume 8 ml, residence time 3.3 h, T-100 C, p (H2/CO) =30 bar, Hz/CO =1/1, substrate solution composition: 9.7% styrene, 4.9% decane, 85.4% benzene (v/v), amount of rhodium 8 X 10-s mol. The variation in conversion can be ascribed to variation in residence time due to small variations in flow speed and temporary refilling of the stock autoclave. Continuous flow experiments Good conversions during a prolonged period can be achieved. So, no deactivation or rhodium leaching was detected in the steady state of the reaction. However, in the initial stage of the reaction, when toluene is used as solvent (Table 2, exp. 5 and 6), a considerable amount of rhodium is eluted from the reactor. This disadvantage can be overcome to some extent when the catalyst precursor and the silica grafted polymer-bound phosphites are mixed before the reaction and stirred under hydroformylation conditions for 24 hours. When the experiments are repeated in benzene (Table 2, exp. 8 and 9), rhodium leaching is completely prevented ( < 0.05% ). However, the calculated kob$ of the reaction is somewhat lower than that in toluene. The system yields stable conversions, and no deactivation was observed.over a period of at least ten days (Fig. 6) . Discussion The batch experiments show that the kinetics and complex formation of the catalytic system is dependent on the solvent used. The observation of peaks at 2011 and 2082 cm-1 in the infrared spectrum of the toluene dissolved system indicates that complexes without phosphites are formed. No such peaks were found in the benzene dissolved system. The sudden increase in reaction rate in toluene is still not completely understood, but can probably be ascribed to non-phosphite bound complexes, Le. phosphite-O rhodium complexes. In the continuous flow reaction, when O rhodium complexes are immediately washed from the reaction vessel, the sudden increase in the activity of the catalyst was not observed. This supports the hypothesis that the reaction rate increase in the batch reaction can be ascribed to free rhodium complexes. The soluble, linear polymer-bound rhodium complexes described previ- 48 T. Jongsma et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 83 (1993) 37-50 ously [ 7 ] served as a model system for the design of the silica-grafted catalyst. According to infrared spectra, the complexes observed for the silica-grafted polymers, however, are different from the non-grafted polymer-bound complexes. Infrared spectroscopy is not powerful enough to unravel the structure of these complexes in detail. Other spectroscopic techniques like NMR and Raman spectroscopy could not be used due to experimental problems (excessive line broadening and fluorescence, respectively). The peak at 2076 cm-1 in the toluene system (Fig. 4) is indicative of the formation of inactive (dimeric or clustered) complexes. These complexes have also been found for the non-grafted polymer-bound system [ 7 ] . The formation of these complexes was ascribed to the reaction of two mono-phosphite coordinated rhodium complexes with each other giving dimeric rhodium complexes. Apparently, the same has happened with the silica-grafted polymer-bound catalyst in toluene. However, the chain loading, a, of the grafted polymer is high and consequently bisphosphite coordinated complexes were expected to be formed. The most reasonable explanation for the formation of low phosphite coordinated complexes is to assume that the grafted polymer chains do not form expanded coils in toluene but become contracted or even adsorbed onto the silica surface. Many ligands are not accessible any more, and only the phosphites on the outer sphere of the adsorbed polymer layer can coordinate to the rhodium. There will be not enough phosphites available to coordinate all rhodium atoms, and non-bound and low phosphite coordinated rhodium complexes will be formed. For the non-grafted polymer toluene is a rather good solvent, i.e., the toluene has a rather favorable interaction with the polymer. However, grafting a polymer onto a surface lowers the entropy of the chains. Especially the translational and rotational freedoms are drastically restricted, but also the conformational entropy decreases when one end of the polymer is fixed [ 13 ] . As indicated by the abnormally high hydrodynamic volume found with GPC (see Experimental), the homopolymers used in the present study are rather rigid. For the rigid polymer chains the conformational entropy will be small, thus adsorption onto the silica or formation of a contracted surface layer may become more favorable for these polymers. Benzene is a better solvent for the polymer than toluene, which probably can be ascribed to having better induced dipole-dipole interactions with the phosphite than toluene. Thus, grafted chains form expanded coils in benzene more eagerly than in toluene, i.e., contraction or adsorption becomes less favorable. When an expanded coil is being formed the accessibility of the polymer-bound phosphites is good and consequently free (non-phosphite bound) complexes are no longer present. This is illustrated by the absence of rhodium in the product flow of the continuous flow reaction. The relatively low activity of the silica-grafted catalyst can be ascribed to the formation of less active, multi-phosphite coordinated complexes. Non-grafted polymers in solution are isolated chains (below the critical overlap concentration c*) and the local ligand concentration is only dependent on the chain loading, a, and the degree T. Jongsma et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 83 (1993) 37-50 49 of expansion of the polymer coil. Grafted polymer chains are immobilized in the vicinity of each other, which leads to enforced chain overlap. Furthermore, for entropic reasons already discussed, the polymer chains will have a slightly more contracted conformation. Both effects lead to increased local phosphite concentrations. In addition, translational and rotational entropy of grafted chains are drastically decreased, which favors the formation of interchain crosslinks. As has already been found for the low molecular weight analogue of the catalyst, tris-phosphite coordinated rhodium complexes are formed when the phosphite concentration is high, and the temperature is low, i.e., when the mobility of the ligand is reduced and association is favored [ 7 ] . Both requirements are present in the benzene dissolved silica-grafted system. Therefore, multi-coordinated rhodium complexes may be formed. Due to steric effects these complexes are less active in hydroformylation reactions. This explains the reduced activity of the benzene dissolved system. When the ligand to rhodium ratio is reduced, the amount of accessible phosphites is reduced, and complexes with lower coordination numbers i.e., more active complexes are likely to be formed. This is reflected in the enhanced activity of the catalyst with a ligand to rhodium ratio of 4 (exp. 9, Table 2) in comparison with the experiment with a phosphite to rhodium ratio of 17 (exp. 8, Table 2). It is noteworthy that even at the low ligand to rhodium ratio of 4, no rhodium leaching was observed. Obviously the coordination complex and the polymer ligand bonds are intrinsically stable, and when all ligands are readily accessible, large excesses of ligands are not needed to keep hold of the catalyst. X244 9387005S 0304-5102(93)87005-S 10.1016/0304-5102(93)87005-S Stable silica-grafted polymer-bound bulky-phosphite modified rhodium hydroformylation catalysts Tjeerd Jongsma Huub van Aert Martijn Fossen Ger Challa ∗ Laboratory of Polymer Chemistry, University of Groningen, Nijenborgh 4, 9747 AG Groningen Netherlands * Corresponding author. Piet W.N.M. van Leeuwen Koninklijke/Shell-Laboratorium Amsterdam (Shell Research B. V.), Badhuisweg 3, 1031 CM Amsterdam Netherlands The present study demonstrates that silica-grafted polymer-bound phosphite modified rhodium complexes can be used in continuous flow reactors. The hydroformylation of styrene was carried out at moderate pressure (p(CO/H2)=30 bar) and temperature (T=1OO°C), yielding constant conversions over a period of at least ten days. Leakage of rhodium is prevented totally and no decay in catalyst activity was observed. These positive results were obtained in benzene as a solvent and for a ligand to rhodium ratio of only 4. When toluene was used as solvent, considerable rhodium leaching was observed. This could be attributed to contraction of the grafted polymer coils in this solvent, leading to incomplete coordination of rhodium. Keywords hydroformylation phosphites polymer-bound catalysts rhodium References 1 D.C. Sherrington Chem. Ind., Jan 1991 15 2 a D. Bailey S. Sanger Chem. Rev. 81 1981 110 b H. Hirai N. Toshima Y. coredata.dc:description: The present study demonstrates that silica-grafted polymer-bound phosphite modified rhodium complexes can be used in continuous flow reactors. The hydroformylation of styrene was carried out at moderate pressure (p(CO/H2)=30 bar) and temperature (T=1OO°C), yielding constant conversions over a period of at least ten days. Leakage of rhodium is prevented totally and no decay in catalyst activity was observed. These positive results were obtained in benzene as a solvent and for a ligand to rhodium ratio of only 4. When toluene was used as solvent, considerable rhodium leaching was observed. This could be attributed to contraction of the grafted polymer coils in this solvent, leading to incomplete coordination of rhodium.
coredata.dc:title: Stable silica-grafted polymer-bound bulky-phosphite modified rhodium hydroformylation catalysts
